editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: SEVERALL POYSONOUS AND SEDICIOUS PAPERS OF Mr. DAVID JENKINS ANSVVERED.
By H. P. BARRESTER of Lincolnes Inne.
LONDON: Printed for Robert Bo≈øtock dwelling in Pauls Church yard, at the Signe of the Kings Head. 1647.

div.head: THE VINDICATION OF JUDGE JENKINS Pri≈øoner in the TOWER, the 29. of April, 1647.

div.p: I Was convened upon Saturday the 10. of this moneth of April before a Committee of the Hou≈øe of Commons, wherein Mr Corbet had the Chair; and I was there to be examined upon ≈øome Que≈øtions then to be propounded to me; to which Que≈øtions I refu≈øed to give any other An≈øwer then that which was ≈øet down in a paper I then delivered to the ≈øaid Mr. Corbet, which followeth in the≈øe words.

Gentlemen, I ≈øtand committed by the Hou≈øe of Commons for high Trea≈øon, fo ‚Ä¢ not acknowledgin ‚Ä¢ , nor obeyin ‚Ä¢ the Power of the two Hou≈øes, by adhering to the king in this War. I deny this to b ‚Ä¢ Trea≈øon; For the ≈øupreame and onely Power by the Laws of the Land is in the king. If I ≈øhould ≈øub ‚Ä¢ it to any examin ‚Ä¢ tion derived from your Power, which by the Ne ‚Ä¢ ative oath ≈øtands in oppo≈øition to the Kings Powe ‚Ä¢ , I ≈øhould conte≈ø≈øe the Power to be in you, and ≈øo condemne my „Äà‚óä„Äâ for a Traytor, which I neither ought no ‚Ä¢ will do.

I am ≈øworn to obey the King, and the Laws of this Land: you have not power to examine m ‚Ä¢ b ‚Ä¢ th ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ e Laws, but by the Kings Writ, Pattent, or Commi≈ø≈øion; if yo ‚Ä¢ ca ‚Ä¢ produce of her thereof, I will an≈øwer the que ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ions you ≈øhall p ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ pound; ot ‚Ä¢ e ‚Ä¢ wi≈øe I cannot an≈øwer thereto, without the breach of my Oath, and the violation of the Laws, which I wil ‚Ä¢ not do to ≈øave my life.

You your ≈øelves, all of you this Parliamen ‚Ä¢ , have ≈øworn that the King is our onely and ≈øupreme Governor: you ‚Ä¢ Prote≈øtation,
your Vow and Covenant, your ≈øolemn League and Covenant, your Declarations, all of them publi≈øh to the Kingdom, that your ≈øcope is the maintenance of the Laws; tho≈øe Laws are and mu≈øt be derived to us, and enlivened by the onely ≈øupreme Governor, the Fountain of ju≈øtice, and the life of the Law, the King. The Parliaments are called by his Writs; the Judges ≈øit by his Pattents, ≈øo of all other Officers; the Cities and Towns corporate, govern by the Kings Charters; and therefore ≈øince by the Law I cannot be examined by you, without a power derived by His Maje≈øty, I neither can, nor will, nor ought you to examine me upon any que≈øtions. But if as private Gentlemen, you ≈øhall be plea≈øed to ask me any que≈øtions, I ≈øhall really and truly an≈øwer every ≈øuch que≈øtion, as you ≈øhall demand.

This paper hath been mi≈ørepre≈øented to the good people of this City by a printed one, ≈øtyling it my Recantation, which I own not; and be≈øides is in it ≈øelf repugnant (ju≈øt like the≈øe times) the Body fals out with the Head. To vindicate my ≈øelf from that Recantation, and to publi≈øh to the world the realitie of the paper then delivered to Mr. Corbet, and the matter therein contained, I have publi≈øhed this en≈øuing Di≈øcour≈øe.
No per≈øon who hath committed Trea≈øon, Murther, or Felony, hath any a≈ø≈øurance at all for ≈øo much as one houre of life, lands or goods, without the Kings gracious pardon. 27 H. 8. ca. 24.
The King is not virtually in the two Hou≈øes at Westminster, whereby they may give any a≈ø≈øurance at all to any per≈øon, in any thing, for any ≈øuch offence.

1. The Hou≈øe of Commons hath declared to the Kingdom in their Declaration of the 28. of November la≈øt to the Scots Papers, pa. 8. That the King at this time is not in a condition to govern. No per≈øon or thing can derive a vertue to other men, or things, which it ≈øelf hath not: and therefore it is impo≈ø≈øible that they ≈øhould have a vertue from the King to govern, which they, declare he hath not him≈øelf to give.

2. The Law of the Land is,
‚Ä¢ Eliz. c. 1. That no per≈øon in any Parliament
hath a voice in the H ‚Ä¢ u≈øe of Commons, but that he ≈øtands a per≈øon to all intents and purp ‚Ä¢ ≈øes as if he had never been elected or returned, if before he ≈øit in the Hou≈øe, he take not his Oath upon the holy Evangelists, that the Kings Maje≈øty is the onely and ≈øupreme Governour over all per≈øons in all Cau≈øes. All the Members of the ≈øaid Hou≈øe have taken it, and at all times as they are returned do take it; otherwi≈øe they have no colour to intermeddle with the publick‚ñ™ Affairs. How doth this ≈øolemn and legall Oath agree with their ≈øaid Declaration, That the King is in no condition to govern. By the one it is ≈øworn, He is the onely ≈øupreme Governor; by the other that he is not in a condition to govern.

3. The Oath is not, that the King was, or ought to be, or had been, before he was ≈øeduced by ill Coun≈øell, our onely and ≈øupreame Governor in all Cau≈øes, over all per≈øons; but in the pre≈øent ten≈øe, that he is our onely and ≈øupreame Governor, at this pre≈øent, in all cau≈øes, and over all per≈øons. So they the ≈øame per≈øons ≈øwear one thing, and declare to the Kingdom the contrary of the ≈øame thing, at the ≈øame time, in that which concerneth the weal of all this Nation.

4. The Mini≈øters in the Pulpits do not ≈øay, what they ≈øwear in the Hou≈øe of Commons. Who ever heard ≈øithence this unnaturall warre, any of their Presbyters attribute that to his Maje≈øtie which they ≈øwear? The rea≈øon is, their Oath is taken at We≈øtmin≈øter among≈øt them≈øelves: that which their Mini≈øters pray and teach, goes among≈øt the people. To tell the people that the King is now their onely and ≈øupreame Governor in all cau≈øes, is conttrary to that the Hou≈øes do now practi≈øe, and to all they act and maintain. They, the two Hou≈øes for≈øooth, are the onely and ≈øupreame Governors in default of the King, for that he hath left his great Coun≈øell, and will not come to them, and yet the King de≈øires to come, but they will not ≈øuffer him, but keep him pri≈øoner at Holdenby: ≈øo well do their actions and O ‚Ä¢ ths agree.

5. They ≈øwear now King Charles is their onely and ≈øupreame Governor; but with a re≈øolution at the time of the Oath taking, and before and after, that he ≈øhall not be onely or ≈øupreame Governor, or onely and ≈øupreame, but not any Governor at all: For there is no point of Government, but for ≈øome yeers pa≈øt they
have taken to them≈øelves, and u≈øed his name onely, to abu≈øe and deceive the people.

6. That this vertuall power is a meer fiction, their Propo≈øiti ‚Ä¢ ns ≈øent to Oxford, to Newca≈øtle, to be ≈øigned by the King, do prove it ≈øo. What needs this ado, if they have the vertuall Power with them at We≈øtmin≈øte ‚Ä¢ ?

7. To affirm that the Kings Power (which is the vertue they talk of) is ≈øeparable from his per≈øon, is high Trea≈øon by the Law of the Land: which is ≈øo declared by that learned man of the ‚Ä¢ aw, Si ‚Ä¢
Edward Cook; ≈øo much magnified by this pre≈øent Parliament, who „Äà‚óä„Äâ 7. part of his Reports in Calvins ca≈øe, fol. 11 ≈øaith thus. In the Reign of Edw: 2. he Sponcers, the Father, a ‚Ä¢ d Son, „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ hatch ‚Ä¢ d in their h ‚Ä¢ arts, invented this damnable and „Äà‚óä„Äâ

I ‚Ä¢ the King do not demean him≈øelf by rea≈øon in the right of his Cro ‚Ä¢ n, his „Äà‚óä„Äâ are bound by Oath to remove th ‚Ä¢ King. 2 Seeing that the King could not be r ‚Ä¢ formed „Äà‚óä„Äâ of
„Äà‚óä„Äâ that ought to be done per a≈øpertee: that is, by f ‚Ä¢ rce. 3. That his lieges be bound to govern in aid of him, and in „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ : All whi ‚Ä¢ h were condemned by two Parliaments, one in the Reign of Ed ‚Ä¢ : 2. call ‚Ä¢ d
‚Ä¢ xilium Hugonis le Spencer; and the other in Anno 1 Edw: 3. cap 2.

And that the naturall body and politick makes one indivi≈øible body, and that the≈øe two bodies incorporate in one per≈øon make one body, and not divers, is re≈øolved as the Law of England, 4. E ‚Ä¢ iz: Plowdon Com: fol: 213. by Si ‚Ä¢
R ‚Ä¢ bert Ca ‚Ä¢ lin, Lord Chief Ju≈øtice of England,
„Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ , Lord Chief Ju≈ø ‚Ä¢ ice of the Common P ‚Ä¢ ea≈øe; the Lord Sa ‚Ä¢ ders, Lord Chief baron of the Exchequer, and by the re≈øt o ‚Ä¢ the Ju ‚Ä¢ ges, viz.

the learned it man of that age, in the kn ‚Ä¢ w ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ dg ‚Ä¢ of the Law, and Cu ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ omes of the Re ‚Ä¢ lm.

8. The Law in all „Äà‚óä„Äâ without any „Äà‚óä„Äâ is and „Äà‚óä„Äâ
been:2 H. ‚Ä¢ Ma ‚Ä¢ na Cha ‚Ä¢ ta. That no Act of Parliament „Äà‚óä„Äâ the Subj ‚Ä¢ cts of the L ‚Ä¢ rd
without the a≈ø≈øent of the King, So in every age till this day, and in every Kings time, as appears by the Acts in print 1 part of the In≈øtit. Sect. 234. in fine. where many of the Law-Books are cited. either for Per≈øon, Lands, goods, or fame. No man can ≈øhew any fillable, letter, or line to the contrary in the books of the Law, or printed Acts of Parliament, in any age in this Land. If the vertuall Power be in the Hou≈øes, there needs no a≈ø≈øent of the Kings. The ≈øtiles of the Acts printed from 9 H. 3. to 1 H. 7. were either, The King ordains at this Parliament, &c. or the King ordaineth by the advice of his Prelates and Barrons, and at the humble Petition of the Commons, &c. In Hen. 7. his time the Stile altered, and hath ≈øithence continued thus, It is ordained by the Kings Maje≈øtie, and the Lords Spirituall and Temporall, and Commons in this pre≈øent Parliament a≈ø≈øembled. So that alwayes the A≈ø≈øent of the King giveth the life to all,7 H. 7. 14. 12 of H. 7. 20 as the ≈øoul to the body; and therefore our Law Books call the King, the Fountain of Ju≈øtice, and the life of the Law.

9. Mercy as well as Ju≈øtice belongs by the Law of the Land onely to the King.2 H. 4. ca. 22. 4 pars in≈øtit. 42. This is confe≈ø≈øed by Mr. Prin ‚Ä¢ , and it is ≈øo without any que≈øtion: The King can onely pardon, and never more ‚Ä¢ au≈øe to have ≈øufficient pardons then in ≈øuch trouble≈øome times as the≈øe;Mr. Prinn in his Treati≈øe of the great Seal, fol. 17. 27 H. 8. c. 24. and God ≈øend us pardons and peace. None can give any pardon, but the King by the Law of the Land: The whole and ≈øole power of pardoning Trea≈øons and Felonies belongs to the King, are the words of the Law, and it is a delu≈øion to take it from any other, and utterly invalid. 27‚ñ™ H. 8. ca. 24.

10. Queen Elizabeth ≈øummoned her fir≈øt Parliament, to be held the 23. of Janna. in the fir≈øt yeer of her Maje≈øties Reign. The Lords and Commons a≈ø≈øembled by force of the ≈øame Writ, the 23. day the Queen fell ≈øick, and could not appear in her per≈øon in Parliament that day, and therefore prorogued it untill the 25. of the ≈øame moneth of Januarie.3 Eliz. Dier 203. Re≈øolved by all the Judges of England, that the Parliament began not the day of the return of the Writ, viz: the 23. of January, when the Lords and Commons appeared; but the 25. of the ≈øaid moneth, when the King came in per≈øon: which ≈øheweth evidently that this vertuall pre≈øence is a meer deluding fiction that hath no ground in Law, rea≈øon, or ≈øen≈øe. They have the King now a Pri≈øoner at Holdenby, with guards upon him, and yet they govern by the vertuall Power of their Pri≈øoner. The≈øe are ≈øome few of the cau≈øes and rea≈øons which moved

div.head: An ANSWER to the Poy≈øonous Seditious Paper of Mr. David Jenkins.
div.p:
MR. David Jenkins in his Paper of the 29. of April la≈øt, lay ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
mo≈øt odious charges upon the Parliament: and con≈øequently upon all that have adhered to the Parliament in this Warre; and le≈ø ‚Ä¢ the≈øe his de≈øperate infu≈øions ≈øhould not work powerfully enough upon the vulgar; he being an ancient practi≈øer in the Law, and promoted to the title of a Judge: he cites Book ca≈øes aga ‚Ä¢ n≈øt the two Hou≈øes, and ≈øeems forward to lay down his life in the cau≈øe.

His 1. Argument runs thus. The Parliament not having the Kings Writ, Patent or Commi≈ø≈øion, cannot do ≈øo much as examine any man: But the Parliament has not the Kings Writ, &c. Ergo: his minor is confirmed thus. If the Kings power remain ≈øolely in him≈øelf, and be not vertually pre≈øent in the two Hou≈øes, then they cannot pretend his Writ, Pattent or Commi≈ø≈øion. But the Kings power is in him≈øelf, and not vertually in the two H ‚Ä¢ u≈øes, ergo, that the Parliament has no vertuall power, he proves thu ‚Ä¢
‚ñ™

1. If the Parliament had in them the Kings vertuall Power, they needed not de≈øire the Kings ratification: they needed not
≈øend any Propo≈øitions to him; but now they ≈øend Propo≈øitions, ergo this vertuall power is but a meer fiction.

‚Ä¢ To affi ‚Ä¢ m that the Kings power is ≈øeparable from his per≈øon, is by the Law adjudged high Trea≈øon: but in the Parliament
„Äà‚óä„Äâ the Kings Power is vertually in them, then they ≈øeparate it
„Äà‚óä„Äâ his per≈øon Ergo.

3. If none can pardon Felony or Trea≈øon except the King,
‚Ä¢ one has the virtua ‚Ä¢ l power of the King, but none can pardon except the King, Ergo,
4. If the King be in no condition to govern, then he is in no condition to derive virtuall power, but, &c.

5. If none can ≈øit in Parliament but he mu≈øt fir≈øt ≈øwear that the
„Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ the onely Supreame Governor over all Per≈øons in all Cau≈øes, then, no Member of the Parliament, nor the whole Parliament, can ≈øuppo≈øe him or them≈øelves ≈øuperiour to the King: but none can ≈øit in Parliament, &c. Ergo,

‚Ä¢ I ‚Ä¢ no Act of Parliament binde the Subject without the Kings
„Äà‚óä„Äâ , then there is no virtuall power in the Parliament without the Kings a≈ø≈øent; but no Act binds, &c. Ergo,

Out of the≈øe premi≈øes which this grave Gentleman judges to be ‚Ä¢ rrefragable, he concludes that the Parliament denies the King to be Supreame Governor, nay to be any Governor at all, in as
„Äà‚óä„Äâ as there is no point of government, He ≈øayes but th ‚Ä¢
Parliament for ≈øome yeers pa≈øt have taken to them≈øelves u≈øing the Kings name, onely to abu≈øe and deceive the people. He ≈øaies further, the Parliament pretends again≈øt the King, becau≈øe that he ha ‚Ä¢ left the great Coun≈øell, and yet the King de≈øires to come to his great Coun≈øell, but cannot becau≈øe he is by them kept
„Äà‚óä„Äâ at Holmby.

„Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ he ≈øaies the Hou≈øes are guilty of pe ‚Ä¢ jur ‚Ä¢ as well as of the „Äà‚óä„Äâ the people, and rebelling again≈øt the King; in as much as at the ≈øame time they ≈øwear him to be onely „Äà‚óä„Äâ Governor, and declare him to be in no condition to govern.
How ea≈øily the≈øe things may be an≈øwered, and refuted, let the world ≈øee.

„Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ cannot be denyed: but the Parliament ≈øits by the Kings Writ, nay if Statute Law be greater then th ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
Kings Writ, it cannot be denyed but the Parliament
„Äà‚óä„Äâ or ough ‚Ä¢ to „Äà‚óä„Äâ by ≈øomething greater then then the Kings
„Äà‚óä„Äâ , And, if it be confe≈ø≈øed
that the Parliament ≈øits by the Kings Writ, but does not Act by the Kings Writ, then it mu≈øt follow that the Parliament is a void vain Court, and ≈øits to no purpo≈øe; nay it mu≈øt al≈øo follow, that the Parliament is of le≈ø≈øe Authority, and of le≈ø≈øe u≈øe then any other inferiour Court. Fora≈ømuch as it is not in the Kings power to controul other Courts, or to prevent them from ≈øitting or Acting.

2. This is a gro≈ø≈øe non ≈øequitu ‚Ä¢
the Kings power is in him≈øelf, Ergo it is not derived to, nor does re≈øide virtually in the Parliament. For the light of the Sun remains imbodied, and unexhau≈øted in the Globe of the Sun, at the ≈øame time as it is diffu≈øed and di≈øplayed through all the body of the air; and who ≈øees not that the King without emptying him≈øelf, gives Commi≈ø≈øions daily of Oier and Terminer to others, which yet he him≈øelf can neither fru≈øtrate nor el ‚Ä¢ de? But for my part I conceive it is a great errour to infer that the Parliament has onely the Kings power, becau≈øe it has the Kings power in it: for it ≈øeems to me that the Parliament does „Äà‚óä„Äâ ≈øit and act by concurrent power, devo ‚Ä¢ ved both from the King and Kingdom; And this in ≈øome things is more obvious and apparent then in others. For by what power does the Parliament grant Sub≈øedies to the King? if onely by the power which the King gives, then the King may take Sub≈øedies without any grant from the Parliament: and if it be ≈øo by a power which the people give to the Parliament, then it will follow, that the Parliament has a power given both by King and Kingdom.

3. The ≈øending Propo≈øitions to the King, and de≈ø ‚Ä¢ ring his concurrence, is ≈øcarce worth an An≈øwer; for Subjects may humbly petition for that which is their ≈øtrict right and property. Nay it may ≈øometimes be≈øeem a ≈øuperior to prefer a ≈øuit to an inferior for matters in them≈øelves due. God him≈øelf has not utterly di≈ødained to be≈øeech his own mi≈øerable, impious, unworthy creatures: be≈øides 'tis not our Tenet that the King has no power, becau≈øe he has not all power; nor that the King cannot at all promote our happine≈ø≈øe, becau≈øe he has no ju≈øt claim to procure our ruine.

4. We affirm not that the Kings power is ≈øeparated from his per≈øon ≈øo as the two Spen≈øers affirmed; neither do we frame conclu≈øions out of that ≈øeparation as the two Spen≈øers did, either
that the King may be removed or mi≈ødemenors, or reformed per a≈øpertee; or that the Subject is bound to govern in aid of him; we onely ≈øay, that his power is di≈øtingui≈øhable from his per≈øon: and when he him≈øelf makes a di≈øtinction betwixt them, commanding one thing by his Legall Writes, Courts and Officers; and commanding another thing extra ‚Ä¢ udicially by word of mouth, letters, or Mini≈øters, we are to obey his Power rather then his Per≈øon.

5. We take not from the King all power of pardoning Delinquents, we onely ≈øay it is not proper to him quarto modo. For if the King pardon him which has murdered my ≈øon, his pardon ≈øhall not ‚Ä¢ ut me off from my appeal: and 'tis more unrea≈øonable that the Kings pardon ≈øhould make a whole State which has ≈øuffered remedile≈ø≈øe, then any private man. So if the King ≈øhould deny indemnity to tho≈øe which in the fury of war have done things unju≈øtifiable by the Laws of Peace, and thereby keep the wounds of the State from being bound up, 'tis equiable that an Act of Indemnity ≈øhould be made forcible another way. And if this will not hold, yet this is no good con≈øequence the King is ab≈øolute in point of pardons, therefore he is ab≈øolute in all things el≈øe; and the Parliament has no power to di≈øcharge Delinquenties, therefore it has no power in other matters.

6 The Parliament has declared the King to be in no condition to govern: but this mu≈øt nor be interpreted rigidly, and without a di≈øtinction: for if the King with his ≈øword drawn in his hand, and pur≈øuing the Parliament and their adherents as Rebels, be not fit for all Acts of Government, „Äà‚óä„Äâ not hereby in≈øinuated that he is „Äà‚óä„Äâ o ‚Ä¢ the habit or righ ‚Ä¢ of governing.
„Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ be unq ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ified now, „Äà‚óä„Äâ is not „Äà‚óä„Äâ for the future. If he may not do things de≈øtructive to the Parliament, he is not „Äà‚óä„Äâ
from returning to the Parliament, or doing „Äà‚óä„Äâ to the Parliament. This is a frivelous civill, and ≈øub ‚Ä¢ erfuge.

7 We ≈øwear that the King is our ≈øupreame Governor over all Per≈øons, and in all cau≈øes; but we do not ≈øwear that he is above all Law, nor above the „Äà‚óä„Äâ of his people, which is the end of the Law, and indeed Paramou ‚Ä¢ t to the Law it ≈øelf. I ‚Ä¢ he be above all Law, or lyable to no re≈øt ‚Ä¢ aint of ou ‚Ä¢ Law, then we are
„Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ the French, or the T ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ks; a ‚Ä¢ d if he be above the pri ‚Ä¢ e end of Law common ≈øafety, then we are not ≈øo „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ the
French, or the Turks. For if the totall ≈øubver≈øion of the French or the Turk were attempted they might by Gods law imprinted in the book of nature ju≈øtifie a ≈øelf-defence; but we mu≈øt remedile≈øly peri≈øh when the King plea≈øes to command our throats. Be≈øides, how acheived the King of England ≈øuch a Supremacy above all Law, and the community it ≈øelf, for who≈øe behoof Law was made? If Gods donation be pleaded, which is not ≈øpeciall to him, or different from what other Kings may pretend too, then to what purpo≈øe ≈øerve our Laws, nay to what purpo≈øe ≈øerve the Laws of other Countreys? for by this generall donation, all Nations are condemned to all ≈øervitude as well as we. If the Law of this Land be appealed to, what Books has Mr. Jenkins read, where has he found out that Lex Regia, whereby the people of England have given away from them≈øelves all right in them≈øelves? Some of our books tell us that we are more free then the French, that the King cannot oppre≈ø≈øe us in our per≈øons, or e≈øtates, by impri≈øonment, denying ju≈øtice, or laying taxes without our con≈øents: other books tell us, that the ≈øafety of the people is the ≈øupreame law, and that the King has both God and the Law for his Superior. But all this is nothing to learned Mr. Jenkins.

8. We admit that no Acts of Parliament are compleat, or formally binding without the Kings a≈ø≈øent: yet this is ≈øtill to be denyed, that therefore without this a≈ø≈øent particularly expre≈øt, the two Hou≈øes can do nothing, nor have any virtuall power at all, no not to examine Mr. Jenkins, nor to do any other thing of like nature, though in order to publick ju≈øtice and ≈øafetie. I have done, and wi≈øh Mr. Jenkins would call in, and lick up again his black, infamous, execrable reproaches, ≈øo filthily vomited out again≈øt the Parliament.

div.head: The Reply of Judge Jenkins to Mr. H. P.
div.p: AFter the ≈øaid Mr. H. P. hath made a recitall of the Heads of my Vindication, he deduceth his An≈øwer unto eight Particulars.

div.head: To the fir≈øt.
div.p: I Was examined by a Committee appointed by the Hou≈øe of Commons: I ≈øay and ≈øaid that the Hou≈øe of Commons have no power to examine me, for that it is no Court, every Court hath power to examine upon Oath, this power the Hou≈øe of Commons never claimed;5 H 4 c. 3. The Court of Pie-Powders, Court-Baron, Hundred Court, 3 H 6. 46. County Court, and every other Court of Record, or not of Record,19 H 6. 43. hath power to examine upon oath, and an examination without Oath,35 H. 6. 5. is a communication onely, examination in Law is upon oath.

There is no Court without a power of triall,Sir Anthony Maynes ca≈øe, Cook 5. pars, Reports, Lit. 2. lib. Sect. 194. 6 H. 4. 1. the Hou≈øe of Commons hath no power to try any offence, nor ever practi≈øed it by Bill, Inditement, Information, Plaint or Originall, to deduce it to triall, nor to try it by Verdict, Demurrer or Examination of witne≈ø≈øes upon Oath, without which there can be no condemnation or judgement; and that which can attain to no rea≈øonable end, the Law rejects as a thing inutile, and u≈øele≈ø≈øe: Sapiens incipit √† fine.

The Writ whereby they are called gives them power Ad faciendum & con≈øentiendum, 4 pars, In≈øtit. fol 4. & 9. to what? to ≈øuch things Quae ibidem de communi Con≈øilio ordinari contigerint, (viz.) in the Parliament: This makes nothing at all for a Court for the Hou≈øe of Commons; that con≈øilium which that Writ intends, is cleared partly by the Writ for choo≈øing Knights, &c. For the King by that Writ is ≈øaid to re≈øolve to con≈øult and treat with the Prelates and Peers of the Kingdom, for and touching the great concernments of the Common-wealth (for the King never fits in the Hou≈øe of Commons;) and this al≈øo is made evident by the Writs to the Prelates, Peers, Judges, and to his Councell at Law; the words in their Writs are, To appear and attend the Parliament, Con≈øilium impen≈øure, the one doth con≈øulere, the other facere & con≈øentire.

The Hou≈øe of Lords,7 H 6. 28. where the King fits in per≈øon, a≈ø≈øi≈øted by his Lords,1 H 7. 20. Judges, Serjeants, Atturney, Sollicitor, Ma≈øters of the Chancery,14 E. 3. ca 5. is a Court of Record to many purpo≈øes, ≈øet down in the books of the Law,1 Pa ‚Ä¢ s, In≈øtit. pa. 21. and the Statutes of the Land; and that Courts is onely in the Hou≈øe of Lords, where the King ≈øits.

A Court mu≈øt either be by the Kings Patent, Statute Law, or by the Common Law,Plowd Com. 319. which is common and con ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ant u≈øage; the Hou≈øe of Commons hath no Patent to be a Court, nor S ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
tute Law to be a Court, nor common u≈øage; they have no
„Äà‚óä„Äâ Book but ≈øince E. 6. time: was there ever Fine by the Hou≈øe of Commons e ‚Ä¢ treated into the Excheque ‚Ä¢ ? For murther o ‚Ä¢ Felony they can impri≈øon no man, much ‚Ä¢ e≈ø≈øe for Trea≈øon; the Hou≈øe which cannot do the le≈ø≈øe cannot do the greater.

I ‚Ä¢ is ordained,25 E 3 c 4. that no man ≈øhall be impri≈øoned, or put out of his Franchi≈øe by the King or his Councell,3‚ñ™ Car Petition of Right. but upon Indictment or pre≈øentment of his good and lawfull Neighbours, where the deed is done, or by originall Writ at the Common Law, and ≈øo is Lex terrae the Law of the Land, mentioned is Magna Charta. cap. 29 expounded; and the ≈øaid Magna Charta and Charta „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ , are declared by the Statute of 25 E 1. „Äà‚óä„Äâ . to be the Common Law of the Land. All Judges and Commi≈ø≈øioners are to proceed, Secundum legem & con≈øuetudinem Regni Angliae, as appears by all proceedings in all Courts, and by all Commi≈ø≈øions: and therefore the Hou≈øe of Commons by them≈øelves proceeding not by Indictment, Pre≈øentment, „Äà‚óä„Äâ Originall Writ, have no power to impri≈øon men, or to put them out of their Franchi ‚Ä¢ e.

This no way trenches upon the Parliament,4 pars, In≈øtit. pag 1 for it is in Law no Parliament withou ‚Ä¢ King and both Hou≈øes;3 Pars. In≈øtit. p. 3. I have onely in my Paper de ‚Ä¢ ivered to Mr. Corbet, applyed my ≈øelf to that Committee, 12 H 7. 20. Prince ca≈øe. that they had no power to examine me; but I never thought, ≈øaid, or wrote, that the Parliament had no power to examine me:8 Pars‚ñ™ Cook. 1 Pars, „Äà‚óä„Äâ p ‚Ä¢ 59. the Law and cu≈øtome of this Land is, that a Parliament hath power over my life, liberty, lands and goods, and over every other Subject;1 H 8 3 but the Hou≈øe of Commons of it ≈øelf hath no ≈øuch power.Dier‚ñ™ 38 H 8 60

For the Lord Cooks relation, that the Hou≈øe of Commons have impo≈øed „Äà‚óä„Äâ ,1 P ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ s, In≈øtit p 19 ‚Ä¢ . and impri≈øoned men in Queen E ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ z ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ths time, and ≈øince; Few facts of late time never „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ
power nor Court,4 „Äà‚óä„Äâ
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ≈øtit ca. Parl. √† „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ
is no good „Äà‚óä„Äâ
for the words of the Statute of 6 H 8 c. 16 that a ‚Ä¢ icence to dep ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ t from the Hou≈øe or Commons for any Member thereof is to be entred of Record in the Book or the Clark of the Parliament,
appointed, or to be appointed for that Hou≈øe, doth not conclude that the Hou≈øe of Commons is a Court of Record.

For fir≈øt, that Law of 6. H. 8. c. 26. handles no ≈øuch que≈øtion, as that, whether the Hou≈øe of Commons be a Court, it is a maxime in all Laws, Lex aliud tractans nil probat, the word (Record) there mentioned, is onely a memoriall of what was done and entered in a Book: A Plaint removed out of the County-Court to the Court of the Common-Pleas, hath the≈øe words in the Writ of remove,Fitzh Nat. Br 70 Recordari facias loquelam, &c. and yet the County-Court is no Court of Record, and ≈øo for ancient Deme≈øne, Fi ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ h. Nat, Br 13. in a Writ of fal≈øe judgement, the words are Recordari facias loquelam, &c. and yet the Court of ancient Deme≈øne is no Court of Record;12 H 4. 23. and ≈øo of a Court Baron, the Law and cu≈øtome of England mu≈øt be pre≈øerved,34 H. 6. 49. or England will be de≈øtroyed, and have neither Law nor cu≈øtome.

Let any man ≈øhew me, that the Court of Lords, or the Hou≈øe of Commons in any age hath made any man a Delinquent (Rege di≈ø≈øentiente) the King contradicting it under his Great Seal. Sir Gi ‚Ä¢ es Mompe≈ø≈øon, Michel, and others of late were condemned by the pro≈øecution of the Hou≈øe of Commons in King James his time; did King James ever contradict it? And ≈øo of ancient times,4 Pars, In≈øtit. Tit. Parl. p. 23. where the Hou≈øe of Peers condemned Latimer in 50. E. 3. the Kings pardon freed him: which ≈øhews cleerly, that the Kings expre≈ø≈øe or implyed a≈ø≈øent mu≈øt of nece≈ø≈øity be had to make a Delinquent.
The Gentleman ≈øaith, That the Parliament fits, or ought to ≈øit by ≈øomething greater then the Kings Writ, &c.

No Parliament did ever ≈øit without the Kings Writ, nor could ever Parliament begin without the Kings pre≈øence in per≈øon,4 Pars, In≈øtit. p. 4. & 6. or by a Guardian of England by Patent under the Kings Great Seal, the King being in remotis, or by Commi≈ø≈øion under the Great Seal to certain Lords repre≈øenting the Kings per≈øon, and hath been thus in all Ages unto this Se≈ø≈øion of Parliament, wherein his Maje≈øtie hath been pre≈ø≈øed, and hath pa≈ø≈øed two Acts of Parliament, one for a Trienniall Parliament, and another for a perpetuall,4 E 3. c. 14. if the Hou≈øes plea≈øe, to ≈øatisfie their de≈øires;36 E. 3. c. 10. how the≈øe two Acts agree one with another, and with
Statute in E. the thirds time,21 I ‚Ä¢ c. the Act of Limitation of Actions, cap. 26. where Parliaments are ordained to be holden every yeer, and what mi≈øchiefs to the people of this Land ≈øuch length of Parliaments will produce by protections and priviledges, to free them and their meniall ≈øervants from all debts during their lives, if they plea≈øe to continue it ≈øo long; and how de≈øtructive to mens actions again≈øt them, by rea≈øon of the Statute of Limitations, which confines their actions to certain yeers, and many other inconveniencies or greater importance, is ea≈øie to under≈øtand?

How can any man affirm, that the two Hou≈øes do act now by the Kings Writ which relates to coun≈øell and Treaty with the King,4 pars, In≈øtit. pa. 14. concerning the King, the defence of his Kingdom, and of the Church of England, there are the three points which it tends to, as appears by the Writ. They keep their King pri≈øoner at Holdenby, and will not ≈øuffer him to con≈øult and treat with them.Vow and Covenant, p. 11. They have made a Vow and Covenant to a≈ø≈øi≈øt the Forces rai≈øed and continued by both Hou≈øes again≈øt the Forces rai≈øed by the King without their con≈øent; and to the ≈øame effect have devi≈øed the Oath which they call the Negative Oath: Is this to defend the Kings Kingdom, or their kingdome?

When by their ≈øolemne League and Covenant they extirpate Bi≈øhops, Deanes and Chapters root and branch, is this to defend the Church of England? (that Church mu≈øt nece≈ø≈øarily be meant, that was the Church of England when the ≈øaid Writ bore te≈øt) they were not ≈øummoned to defend a Church that was not in being;3 Pars, Cook. De ‚Ä¢ n and Chapter of Norwich. to de≈øtroy and defend the Church are very contrary things; the Church is not defended, when they take away and ≈øell the Lands of the Church.

The Gentleman ≈øaith, The King cannot controll other Courts of Justice, or prevent them from ≈øitting or acting, and therefore not the two Hou≈øes, &c. It is true, the King cannot controll or prevent his other Courts, for that they are his ordinarie Courts or common ju≈øtice, to admini≈øter common „Äà‚óä„Äâ unto all men, according to the fixed Laws. The Hou≈øes make no Court without the King, they are no body Co ‚Ä¢ porate without the King, nor Parliament without the King, they all
make one corporate body, one Court called the Parliament, wherof the King is the head,4 Pars, In≈øtit. p. 1. and the Court is in the Lords hou≈øe, where the King is pre≈øent: and as a man is no man without a head, ≈øo the Hou≈øes ≈øevered from the King, as now they are, have no power at all, and they them≈øelves by levying War again≈øt the King, and impri≈øoning of him, have made the State for not di≈ø≈øolving, adjourning, or proroging this Parliament of no effect, by the ≈øaid Acts of their owne; they ≈øit to no purpo≈øe without his a≈ø≈øent to their Bills, they will not ≈øuffer him to con≈øult with them, and treat and rea≈øon with them, whereby we may di≈øcerne what Bills are fit to pa≈ø≈øe, and what not, which in all Ages the Kings of this Land have enjoyed as their undoubted Rights, and therefore they ≈øit to no purpo≈øe by their owne di≈øobedience and fault.

For the ordinary Courts at We≈øtmin≈øter, 27 H. 8. c. 24, 28. H. 8 11. Dier. the Iudges in all tho≈øe Courts are Iudges by the Kings Patent or Writ, otherwi≈øe they are no Iudges: the Hou≈øes can make no Iudges, they are no Iudges at all who are made by them; the whole and ≈øole power of making Iudges, belongs to the King: the King cannot controle or prevent his own Iudges from ≈øitting or acting, but the Hou≈øes he may for they are not the Kings Iudges, but the Iudges of the two Hou≈øes. 2 R, 3. 11. In his other Courts, the King commits his power to his Iudges by his patent, and they are ≈øworne to doe common right to all men, and the King is ≈øworne not to let them from ≈øo doing: the King cannot judge in tho≈øe Courts, nor controule; but the King is both Iudge and Controller in the Court of Parliament: Quoad. Acts, for his a≈ø≈øent or di≈ø≈øent doth give life or death to all Bils. Many Lawyers have much to an≈øwer to God, this Kingdom, and to po≈øterity, for puzling the people of this Land with ≈øuch Fancies, as the Gentl‚ñ™ who wrote the An≈øwer to my Paper, and others have publi≈øhed in the≈øe Troubles, which hath bin none of the lea≈øt cau≈øes of the ray≈øing and continuing of them: And ≈øo I have done with the fir≈øt part of his an≈øwer.

div.head: A. D. 2.
div.p: For the Non ≈øequitur, in the ≈øecond Section of the Gent‚ñ™ An≈øwer, the Antecedent and the Con≈øequent are his own.

q.l: Quem recitas meus e≈øt (√¥ Fidentine!) libellus:
Sed mal√® dum recitas incipit e≈ø≈øe tuus.

div.p:
My words are, that the King is not vertually in the two hou≈øes
at We≈øtmin≈øter, to enable them to grant pardons, for that whole and ≈øole power by the Law belongs to the King. My Paper hath no ≈øuch thing, as that the KINGS power cannot be derived to others or the vertue of his power: 27 H. c. 24. For His power, and the vertue of His power is in all Patents to his Iudges, in Charters to Corporations, in Commi≈ø≈øions of all ≈øorts, and in the Parliament a≈ø≈øembled by force of his Writ of Summons, ≈øo long as they obey him; but when they renounce that power, and claime it not from the King, and declare to the Kingdome that hee is not in condition to governe, and impri≈øon him, and u≈øurpe to them≈øelves all Royall Authority, as the two Hou≈øes now doe, no rea≈øonable man can affirme that they act by the power of their Pri≈øoner, who hath no power to give them, that by force of Arms take all the power to them≈øelves.

The Gentl. ≈øaith, the King grants Commi≈ø≈øions daily of Oyer and Terminer,4 E 4, 39. which hee cannot fru≈øtrate nor elude. 5 E. 44. The King may revoke and di≈øcharge the Commi≈ø≈øion by his Writ,1 E ‚Ä¢ . Dy ‚Ä¢ r 165. as hee may remove all Judges, and place other men in their roome; and many Kings death determines all the Iudges Parents of We≈øtmin≈øter-Hall, 1 Mar. Bro ‚Ä¢ ks ca≈øe 447. Commi≈ø≈øions of Oyer and Terminer, &c. and ≈øo hee might di≈ø≈øolve both Hou≈øes in all times, by his Writ under the Great Scale, untill that by this Parliament, by his owne conce≈ø≈øion, the King of his goodne≈ø≈øe hath ≈øecluded him≈øelfe; which goodnes hath bin full ill requi ‚Ä¢ ed.

The Gentl. affirmes, That the power the Parliament hath, is concurrent from the King and Kingdome; which he conceives, is proved by the Grant of Sub≈øidies to the King by the Parliament. The mi≈øtaking of this word (Parliament) hath beene mi≈øchievous in the≈øe times to this Land,4 Pars, in≈øtit. p. 1. and it is affectedly mi≈øtaken, which makes the ≈øinne the greater, for the two Hou≈øes are not the Parliament as before is declared; and at this time ≈øo to inculcate it, when all men know, that of the 120. Peeres of the Kingdom, who were temporall Peeres before the troubles, there are not not above 30. in the Lords hou≈øe, and in the hou≈øe of Commons about 200. of the prime Gent. of the Kingdom left the Hou≈øe, and adhered to his Maje≈øty, who is impri≈øoned by them, ≈øhews no ≈øuch candor as to be de≈øired

It is true,25 Eliz. 1. Confirmatio chartarum, cap. 6. that no Tallage can be layd upon the People of this Land, but by their con≈øent in Parliament, as appeareth by the Lawes mentioned in the margent, but you ≈øhall finde in Mr. Seldens
learned Book, 24 Eli. 1. cap. 1. de Tallagio non concedendo. called Mare Clau≈øum, a number of Pre≈øidents in Henry the thirds time for Ship-money, ju≈øtly condemned this Parliament, to which his Maje≈øty a≈ø≈øented; and in truth, that Ship-money was condemned before, by the ≈øaid two Statutes of 25. E. 1. & 34. E. 1. de Tallagio non concedendo. Dane-gelt, Englitery, and many grievous burthens were layd upon the people, and born, untill that memorable Princes time. But I am of opinion, that the Common Law of the Land did alwayes re≈øtraine Kings from all Sub≈øidies and Tallages, but by con≈øent in Parliament; which doth appeare by Magna Charta the la≈øt chap. where the Prelates, Lords, and Comminalty gave the King the fifteenth part of their moveables. In truth it is no manner of con≈øequence, becau≈øe the King cannot take what he plea≈øeth of the ≈øubjects goods, that therefore they have a concurrent power in Parliament: there have bin many Parliaments, and no Sub≈øidies granted, Parliaments may be without Sub≈øidies, but Sub≈øidies cannot be without Parliaments: of ancient time Parliaments rarely granted any unle≈ø≈øe it were in the time of forraine Wars; and in my time, Q. E. refu≈øed a Sub≈øidie granted in Parliament, and in the Parliament of 1. Jac. none were granted. The Gent. ≈øhould make a con≈øcience of blinding the people with ≈øuch untrue colours, to the ruine of King and people.

div.head: A. D. 3.
div.p: The Gent. affirms, That the ≈øending Propo≈øitions to the King, and de≈øiring his concurrence, is ≈øcarce worth an an≈øwer, for Subjects may humbly petition for that which is their ≈øtrict right and property, &c. The Propo≈øitions ≈øent to Newcastle, are in print; wherein the two Hou≈øes are ≈øo farre from humbly petitioning, that they ≈øtile not them≈øelves his Maje≈øties Subjects, as appeares by the Propo≈øitions.

That they have a ≈øtrict right or property to any on of the≈øe Propo≈øitions, is a ≈øtrange a≈ø≈øertion, every one of them being again≈øt the Lawes now in force: Have the two Hou≈øes a ≈øtrict right and property, to lay upon the people what Taxes they ≈øhal judg meet? To pardon all trea≈øons, &c. that is one of their Propo≈øitions. Have they a ≈øtrict right and property to pardon them≈øelves? and ≈øo for all the re≈øt of their Propo≈øitions.

The≈øe Propo≈øitions have been Voted by both Hou≈øes,12 H. 7. 20 the Kings a≈ø≈øent (they being drawne into Bills) makes them Acts of Parliament: 1 Iac. c. 1. Hath the King no right to a≈ø≈øent or di≈ø-a≈ø≈øent?1 Car. c. 7. Was the
≈øending but a Complement? All our Law-bookes and Statutes ≈øpeak otherwi≈øe. This Gentl. and others, mu≈øt give an account one time or other for ≈øuch delu≈øions put upon the people.

div.head: A. D. 4.
div.p: The Gent. ≈øaith, They affirme not, that the Kings power is ≈øeparated from his per≈øon, ≈øo as the two Spencers affirmed, &c. His Maje≈øties per≈øon is now at Holnby under their Guards; have they not ≈øevered his power from him, when by no power they have left him, he can have two of his Chaplaines, who have not taken their Covenant to attend him for the exerci≈øe of his Con≈øcience?

For the three Conclu≈øions of the Spencers, 15 Ed. 2. Exilium Hugonis do not the two Hou≈øes act every of them? They ≈øay his Maje≈øty hath broken his tru≈øt, touching the government of his people: They have rai≈øed Armies to take him, 1 E 3. c. 2. Calv. ca≈øe 7 Pars, Reports 11. they have taken him, and impri≈øoned him; they govern them≈øelves; they make Laws, impo≈øe Taxes, make Iudges, Sheriffes, and take upon them omnia in≈øignia ≈øummae pote≈øtatis: Is not this to remove the King for mi≈ødemeanours, to reforme per a≈øpert√®, to governe in aide of him; the three conclu≈øions of the Spencers? Doe they think the good people of England are becom ≈øtupid, and will not at length ≈øee the≈øe things?

The Gentl. ≈øaith,Plowd. 4. E. 213. the Kings power and his per≈øon are indivi≈øible. they doe not ≈øeparate his power from his Per≈øon, but di≈øtingui≈øh it, &c. His power is in his legall Writs, Courts, and Officicers: when they counterfeit the Great Seale, and ≈øeale Writs with the ≈øame, make Iudges them≈øelves, Courts and Officers, by their own Ordinances again≈øt his con≈øent, declared under his true Great Seale of England (not by word of mouth, letters, or mini≈øters onely) their Seale is obeyed, their own Writs, their own Iudges, their owne Courts, their own Officers, and not the Kings: The time will come when ≈øuch ≈øtrange actions and di≈øcour≈øes will be lamented.

div.head: A. D. 5.
div.p:
The Gentl. goes on, Stanfor. Pleas. 99. 27. H. 8. c. 24. Dier. 163.
Wee take not from the King all power of pardoning Delinquents, we only ≈øay it is not proper to him quarto modo, &c. What doe you meane by quarto modo? I am ≈øure, Omnis Rex Angliae, ≈øolus Rex & ≈øemper Rex can doe it, and none el≈øe: read the bookes of the Law to this purpo≈øe collected by that Reverend and learned Iudge Stanford, from all antiquity to his time, who dyed in the la≈øt yeare of King Philip and Queene Maries Reigne,
you ≈øhall find this a truth undenyable; and this power was never que≈øtioned in any age in any book by any untill this time, that every thing is put to the que≈øtion: You Gentlemen who profe≈ø≈øe the Law, and maintaine the party again≈øt the King, return at length, and bring not ≈øo much ≈øcandall upon the Law, (which pre≈øerves all) by publi≈øhing ≈øuch incredible things.

We hold only what the Law holds,1 Pars. In≈øtit. p. 44. Plowd. 3. Eliz. 236, 237. the Kings Prerogative and the Subjects Liberty are determined, and bounded, and mea≈øured by the written Law what they are; we do not hold the King to have any more power, neither doth His Maje≈øty claime any other but what the Law gives him; the two Hou≈øes by the Law of this Land have no colour of power, either to make Delinquents, or pardon Delinquents, the King contradicting: (and the Army under Sir Thomas Fairfax (howbeit but Souldiers) do now under≈øtand that to be Law, and doe now evidently ≈øee and a≈ø≈øuredly know, that it is not an Ordinance of the two Hou≈øes, but an act of Parliament, made by the King, Lords and Commons that will ≈øecure them, and let this Army remember their executed fellow Souldiers) And the Law was alwayes ≈øo taken by all men untill the≈øe troubles, that have begot Mon≈øters of Opinions.

div.head: A. D. 6.
div.p: The Gentl. ≈øayes, The Parliament hath declared the King to be in no condition to Governe, &c.

There is no end of your di≈øtinctions, I and you profe≈øs the Law, ≈øhew me Law for your di≈øtinctions, or letter, ≈øyllable, or line, in any age in the Bookes of the Law, that the King may in one time be in no condition to govern, and yet have the habit of governing, and another time he may (viz.) when the two Hou≈øes will ≈øuffer him: the Law ≈øaith thus, Vbi lex non di≈øtinguit, non est di≈øtinguendum.

Hee ≈øayes, The King is not barred from returning to His Parliament, (as he calls the two Hou≈øes) he knowes the contray, the whole City knowes the contrary, No ‚Ä¢ juris con≈øulti ≈øumus ≈øacerdotes, (as Ju≈øtinian the Emperour hath it, in the fir≈øt Book of his In≈øtitutions) and therefore knowledge and truth ≈øhould come from our lips: Worthy and ingenious men will remember, and reflect upon that pa≈ø≈øage of that good and wi≈øe man Seneca, Non quaitur, ≈øed qua eundum; follow not the rayes of the Lawyers of the Hou≈øe of Commons. God forgive them, I am ≈øure the King will if they be wi≈øe and ≈øeeke it in time.

div.head: A D. 7.
div.p: The Gentl. ≈øayes, We ≈øweare that the King is our ≈øupreame Governor over all per≈øons and in all cau≈øes, &c. Why hath he left out the word (only?) for the oath the Members now take, is, that KING Charles is now the only and ≈øupreme Governour in all cau≈øes, 5 Eliz. c. 1. Cawdreys ca≈øe 5 pars, fol. 1. over all per≈øons, and yet they keep their only Supreme Governour now in pri≈øon, and act now in Parliament by vertue of their Pri≈øoners Writ, and by a concurrent power in this Parliament, and by their own ≈øtrict right and property, (as the Gentl. affirmes in his an≈øwer) the≈øe things agree well with their Oath,This Oath is allowed by the Common Law of the Land. that the King is the only Supreme Governour in all cau≈øes, over all per≈øons; this Oath is taken now in the Parliament time, by all the Members of the Hou≈øe of Commons, and is required by the Law to bee taken in all Parliaments, otherwi≈øe they have no power, nor colour to meddle with the publike affaires.

This Oath being taken in Parliament, that the King is the only and Supreme Governour in all cau≈øes, then it followes in Parliament cau≈øes; ever all per≈øons, then over the two Hou≈øes; let them keep this Oath, and we ≈øhall bee ≈øure of peace in the Land: and good Lawyers ought to de≈øire peace, both for the publike good and their private, and not di≈øhonour that Noble profe≈ø≈øion, as many doe in this mi≈øerable time.

The Gent. ≈øayes, We do not ≈øweare that the King is above all Law, nor above the ≈øafety of his people; neither doe we ≈øo ≈øweare, but His Maje≈øty and we will ≈øweare the contrary, and have ≈øworne, and have made good, and will by Gods grace make good our Oath to the world, that the King is not above the Law, nor above the ≈øafety of his people, the Law and the ≈øafety of his people are his ≈øafety, his honour and his ≈øtrength.

div.head: A D. 8.
div.p:
The Gentl. concludes, That Acts of Parliament are not formally binding, nor compleat without the Kings a≈ø≈øent, yet the Hou≈øes have a virtuall power without the Kings particular a≈ø≈øent, to doe things in order to publike Ju≈øtice and ≈øafety, (viz.) In ≈øetting up the Exci≈øe, in rai≈øing and maintaining of Armies, in taxing the people at pleawith fifth and twentieth part, fifty Sub≈øidies, Seque≈øtrations, Lo ‚Ä¢ nes, Compo≈øitions, impri≈øoning the King, aboli≈øhing the
Common-Prayer-Book, ≈øelling the Churches Lands, &c. all the≈øe are in order to publike Iu≈øtice and ≈øafety.

Mr. H. P. you are of my profe≈ø≈øion, I be≈øeech you, for the good of your Country, for the Honour of our Science, per≈øwade your ≈øelfe and others, as much as in you lyes, to believe and follow the monition and Councell of that memorable, reverend, and profoundly Learned in the Lawes and Cu≈øtoms of the Land, the Lord Coke, who writes as becomes a great and a learned Iudge of the Law (a per≈øon much magnified by the two Hou≈øes) in the≈øe words: Peru≈øe over all Bookes,3 Pars, In≈øt p. 36. Records and Hi≈øtories, and you ≈øhall finde a Principle in Law, a Rule in Rea≈øon, and a tryall in Experience, that Trea≈øon doth ever perduce fatall and finall de≈øtruction to the offender, and never attaines to the de≈øired end (two incidents in≈øeperable thereunto) and therefore let all men abandon it, as the poy≈øonous bait of the devill, and follow the Precept in holy Scripture, SERVE GOD, HONO∆≤R THE KING, AND HAVE NO COMPANY WITH THE SEDITIO∆≤S.

div.head: CONCLUSION.
div.p: I Say againe, that without an Act of Oblivion, a Gracious generall pardon from his Maje≈øty, the Arreares of the Souldiers payd, a favourable regard had to tender Con≈øciences, there will bee neither Truth nor Peace in this Land, nor any man ≈øecure of any thing he hath.
